<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Successor&#146;s accumulated amortization was $19,095 as of December&nbsp;31, 2014, which includes accumulated
	amortization of foreign subsidiaries translated using exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date. The Successor&#146;s amortization expense for amortizable assets was $19,128, including the adjustments resulting from fluctuations in foreign
	currency exchange rates, for the period from June&nbsp;30, 2014 through December&nbsp;31, 2014 and the Predecessor&#146;s expense was $11,093 for the six months period ended June&nbsp;29, 2014. The Predecessor&#146;s amortization expense for
	amortizable assets was $22,112 and 21,752 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2012, respectively. For the years ending December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019, the Successor&#146;s amortization expense for amortizable assets is
	estimated to be $38,187, $38,187, $38,187, $38,187, and $38,187, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	77
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	9.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Long-Term Debt:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;30, 2014, Hillman and certain of its subsidiaries closed on a $620,000 senior secured credit facility (the &#147;Senior
	Facilities&#148;), consisting of a $550,000 term loan and a $70,000 revolving credit facility (&#147;Revolver&#148;). The term loan portion of the Senior Facilities has a seven year term and the Revolver has a five year term. For the first fiscal
	quarter after June&nbsp;30, 2014, the Senior Facilities provide term loan borrowings at interest rates based on LIBOR plus a LIBOR Spread of 3.50%, or an Alternate Base Rate (&#147;ABR&#148;) plus an ABR Spread of 2.50%. The LIBOR is subject to a
	minimum floor rate of 1.00% and the ABR is subject to a minimum floor of 2.00%. Additionally, the Senior Facilities provide Revolver borrowings at interest rates based on LIBOR plus a LIBOR Spread of 3.25%, or an ABR plus an ABR Spread of 2.25%.
	There is no minimum floor rate for Revolver loans. After the initial fiscal quarter, the borrowing rate shall be adjusted quarterly on a prospective basis on each adjustment date based upon total leverage ratio for initial term loans and the senior
	secured leverage ratio for Revolver loans. For the fiscal quarter beginning after December&nbsp;31, 2014, the term loan borrowings will be at an adjusted interest rate of 4.5% and the Revolver loans will be at interest rates based on Libor plus a
	Libor spread of 3.25% or an ABR plus an ABR spread of 2.25%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Concurrent with the consummation of the Merger Transaction, Hillman Group issued $330,000
	aggregate principal amount of its senior notes due July&nbsp;15, 2022 (the &#147;6.375% Senior Notes&#148;), which are guaranteed by Hillman Companies and its domestic subsidiaries other than the Hillman Group Capital Trust. Hillman Group pays
	interest on the 6.375% Senior Notes semi-annually on January&nbsp;15 and July&nbsp;15 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Prior to the consummation of the Merger Transaction,
	the Company, through Hillman Group, was party to a Senior Credit Agreement (the &#147;Prior Credit Agreement&#148;), consisting of a $30,000 revolving credit line and a $384,400 term loan. The facilities under the Prior Credit Agreement had a
	maturity date of May&nbsp;28, 2017. In addition, the Company, through Hillman Group, had issued $265,000 in aggregate principal amount of 10.875% Senior Notes that were scheduled to mature on June&nbsp;1, 2018. In connection with the Merger
	Transaction, both the Prior Credit Agreement and the 10.875% Senior Notes were repaid and terminated.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	78
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage79"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	9.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Long-Term Debt: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company pays interest to the Hillman Group Capital Trust (&#147;Trust&#148;) on the Junior Subordinated
	Debentures underlying the Trust Preferred Securities at the rate of 11.6%&nbsp;per annum on their face amount of $105,443, or $12,231 per annum in the aggregate. The Trust will redeem the Trust Preferred Securities when the Junior Subordinated
	Debentures are repaid, or at maturity on September&nbsp;30, 2027. The Trust distributes an equivalent amount to the holders of the Trust Preferred Securities. Pursuant to the Indenture that governs the Trust Preferred Securities, the Trust is able
	to defer distribution payments to holders of the Trust Preferred Securities for a period that cannot exceed 60 months (the &#147;Deferral Period&#148;). During a Deferral Period, the Company is required to accrue the full amount of all interest
	payable, and such deferred interest payable would become immediately payable by the Company at the end of the Deferral Period. There were no deferrals of distribution payments to holders of the Trust Preferred Securities in 2014 or 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Senior Facilities provide for customary events of default, including but not limited to, payment defaults, breach of representations or covenants,
	cross-defaults, bankruptcy events, failure to pay judgments, attachment of its assets, change of control, and the issuance of an order of dissolution. Certain of these events of default are subject to notice and cure periods or materiality
	thresholds. The Company is also required to comply, in certain circumstances, with a senior secured net leverage ratio covenant. This covenant only applies if, at the end of a fiscal quarter, there are outstanding Revolver borrowings in excess of
	35% of the total revolving commitments. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Revolver loan had no amounts outstanding and the outstanding letters of credit were $3.7 million. The $3.7 million outstanding usage represented 5% of total revolving
	commitments and this financial covenant was not in effect. The occurrence of an event of default permits the lenders under the Senior Facilities to accelerate repayment of all amounts due. The Company was in compliance with all provisions and
	covenants of the Senior Facilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, long-term debt is summarized as follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company had $66,277 available under our revolving credit agreement and letter of credit
	commitments outstanding of $3,723. The Company had outstanding debt of $547,857 under our secured credit facilities at December&nbsp;31, 2014, consisting of $547,250 in Term B loans and $607 in capitalized lease and other obligations. The term loan
	consisted of $547,250 in Term B Loans currently at a three (3)&nbsp;month LIBOR rate of 4.50%. The capitalized lease and other obligations were at various interest rates.
</P>

	&#150; Fair Value Measurements.

	The rental expense for all operating leases was $6,511, $5,890, $11,788 and $8,787 for the Successor period from June&nbsp;30,

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	11.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Deferred Compensation Plan:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains a deferred compensation plan for key employees (the &#147;Nonqualified Deferred Compensation Plan&#148; or
	&#147;NQDC&#148;) which allows the participants to defer up to 25% of salary and commissions and up to 100% of bonuses to be paid during the year and invest these deferred amounts into certain Company directed mutual fund investments, subject to the
	election of the participants. The Company is permitted to make a 25% matching contribution on deferred amounts up to $10, subject to a five year vesting schedule.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of Successor&#146;s period ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and Predecessor&#146;s year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, the Company&#146;s consolidated balance
	sheets included $2,244 and $4,386, respectively, in restricted investments representing the assets held in mutual funds to fund deferred compensation liabilities owed to the Company&#146;s current and former employees. The current portion of the
	restricted investments was $494 and $2,856 as of Successor&#146;s period ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and Predecessor&#146;s year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The assets held in the NQDC are classified as an investment in trading securities. The Company recorded trading gains and offsetting compensation expense of
	$43, $95, $364, and $329 for the Successor&#146;s period ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, Predecessor&#146;s period ended June 29, 2014, and Predecessor&#146;s years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, and 2012, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the Successor&#146;s period ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, Predecessor&#146;s period ended June 29, 2014, and Predecessor&#146;s years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, and 2012, distributions from the deferred compensation plan aggregated $0, $2,893, $864, and $357, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	80
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	12.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Guaranteed Preferred Beneficial Interest in the Company&#146;s Junior Subordinated Debentures:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In September 1997, The Hillman Group Capital Trust, a Grantor trust, completed a $105,446 underwritten public offering of 4,217,724 Trust
	Preferred Securities (&#147;TOPrS&#148;). The Trust invested the proceeds from the sale of the preferred securities in an equal principal amount of 11.6% Junior Subordinated Debentures of Hillman due September 2027.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Trust distributes monthly cash payments it receives from the Company as interest on the debentures to preferred security holders at an annual rate of
	11.6% on the liquidation amount of $25.00 per preferred security.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the public offering of TOPrS, the Trust issued $3,261 of trust
	common securities to the Company. The Trust invested the proceeds from the sale of the trust common securities in an equal principal amount of 11.6% Junior Subordinated Debentures of Hillman due September 2027. The Trust distributes monthly cash
	payments it receives from the Company as interest on the debentures to the Company at an annual rate of 11.6% on the liquidation amount of the common security.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company may defer interest payments on the debentures at any time, for up to 60 consecutive months. If this occurs, the Trust will also defer distribution
	payments on the preferred securities. The deferred distributions, however, will accumulate interest at a rate of 11.6%&nbsp;per annum. The Trust will redeem the preferred securities when the debentures are repaid, or at maturity on
	September&nbsp;30, 2027. The Company may redeem the debentures before their maturity at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the debentures redeemed, plus accrued interest. When the Company redeems any debentures before their maturity,
	the Trust will use the cash it receives to redeem preferred securities and common securities as provided in the trust agreement. The Company guarantees the obligations of the Trust on the Trust Preferred Securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has determined that the Trust is a variable interest entity and the holders of the Trust Preferred Securities are the primary beneficiaries of the
	Trust. Accordingly, the Company has de-consolidated the Trust. Summarized below is the financial information of the Trust as of December&nbsp;31, 2014:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The non-current assets for the Trust relate to its investment in the 11.6% junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures
	of Hillman due September&nbsp;30, 2027.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The TOPrS constitute mandatorily redeemable financial instruments. The Company guarantees the obligations of the
	Trust on the Trust Preferred Securities. Accordingly, the guaranteed preferred beneficial interest in the Company&#146;s junior subordinated debentures is presented in long-term liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	81
</P>

<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>

<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<B>
	12.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Guaranteed Preferred Beneficial Interest in the Company&#146;s Junior Subordinated Debentures: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;30, 2014, the Junior Subordinated Debentures were recorded at the fair value of $131,141 based
	on the price underlying the Trust Preferred Securities of $30.32 per share upon close of trading on the NYSE Amex on that date plus the liquidation value of the trust common securities. The Company is amortizing the premium on the Junior
	Subordinated Debentures of $22,437 over their remaining life.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	13.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Common and Preferred Stock:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<U>
	Common Stock
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	After consummation
	of the Merger Transaction, The Hillman Companies, Inc. has one class of common stock. All outstanding shares of The Hillman Companies, Inc. common stock are owned by Holdco. The management shareholders of Holdco do not have the ability to put their
	shares back to Holdco.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the terms of the Predecessor Stockholders Agreement for the Predecessor Holdco common stock, management shareholders had the
	ability to put their shares back to Predecessor Holdco under certain conditions, including death or disability. ASC 480-10-S99 requires shares to be classified outside of permanent equity if they can be redeemed and the redemption is not solely
	within control of the issuer. Further, if it is determined that redemption of the shares is probable, the shares are marked to fair value at each balance sheet date with the change in fair value recorded in additional paid-in capital. The
	Predecessor Company determined that redemption of the shares was probable as they could be put back to Predecessor Holdco upon death or disability. Accordingly, the 161.2 shares of common stock held by management as of December&nbsp;31, 2013 were
	recorded outside permanent equity. These shares were adjusted to the fair value of $16,975 as of December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<U>
	Preferred Stock
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Hillman Companies has one class of preferred stock, with 5,000 shares authorized and none issued or outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2014
	or 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	14.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Stock-Based Compensation:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	OHCP HM Acquisition Corp. 2010 Stock Option Plan
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Effective May&nbsp;28, 2010, the Predecessor established the OHCP HM Acquisition Corp. 2010 Stock Option Plan, as amended (the &#147;Predecessor Option
	Plan&#148;), pursuant to which Predecessor Holdco granted non-qualified stock options for the purchase of Predecessor Holdco common stock. Immediately prior to the consummation of the Merger Transaction, there were outstanding options to purchase
	44,180 shares of Predecessor Holdco common stock. In connection with the Merger Transaction, the Predecessor Option Plan was terminated, and all options outstanding thereunder were cancelled. Upon consummation of the Merger Transaction, each
	outstanding option to purchase shares of Predecessor Holdco common stock was converted into the right to receive, in cash, a portion of the merger consideration in the Merger Transaction.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	82
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage83"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>

<B>
	Stock-Based Compensation: (continued)
</B>

</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Option holders were not required by the terms of the Predecessor Option Plan or the Predecessor Stockholders
	Agreement to hold the shares for any period of time following exercise. Liability classification was required because this arrangement permits the holders to put the shares back without being exposed to the risks and rewards of the shares for a
	reasonable period of time. Consistent with past practice, the Company elected to use the intrinsic value method to value the options. Immediately prior to the cancelation of the Predecessor Option Plan, the stock option liability was $48,517.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	HMAN Group Holdings Inc. 2014 Equity Incentive Plan
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Effective June&nbsp;30, 2014, Holdco established the HMAN Group Holdings Inc. 2014 Equity Incentive Plan (the &#147;2014 Equity Incentive Plan&#148;), pursuant
	to which Holdco may grant options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock, and other stock-based awards for up to an aggregate of 44,021.264 shares of its common stock. The 2014 Equity Incentive Plan is administered by a committee of the Holdco
	board of directors. Such committee determines the terms of each stock-based award grant under the 2014 Equity Incentive Plan, except that the exercise price of any granted options and the grant price of any granted stock appreciation rights may not
	be lower than the fair market value of one share of common stock of Holdco as of the date of grant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, Holdco granted a total of 35,817.010
	non-qualified stock options with certain time-vesting and performance vesting conditions under the 2014 Equity Incentive Plan. The options were granted with an exercise price equal to the grant date fair value of the underlying securities. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, a total of 8,204.254 shares were available for future stock-based award grants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of 18,208.5 time-vested options
	granted by Holdco was estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option pricing model with the following assumptions: dividend yield equaling 0%, risk-free interest rate of 2.1%, expected volatility assumed to be 32.0%, and expected term
	from 6.5 years to 6.75 years. The fair value of an option was $372.598.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Compensation expense of $675 was recognized in the accompanying consolidated
	statements of Comprehensive Loss for the period from June&nbsp;30, 2014 through December&nbsp;31, 2014. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, there was $6,110 of unrecognized compensation expense for unvested common options. The expense will be recognized
	as a charge to earnings over a weighted average period of approximately 4.5 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Holdco also granted 17,608.5 performance-based stock options that
	ultimately vest depending upon satisfaction of conditions that only arise in the event of a sale of the Company. No compensation expense will be recognized on these stock options unless it becomes probable the performance conditions will be
	satisfied.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	83
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<U>
	OHCP HM Acquisition Corp. Deferred Stock Unit Plan U.S.:
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Effective December&nbsp;31, 2013, Predecessor Holdco established the OHCP HM Acquisition Corp. Deferred Stock Unit Plan U.S. for Senior Officers (the &#147;DSU
	Plan&#148;). The DSU Plan permitted an eligible executive to elect to have a short-term incentive award paid in the form of deferred stock units, which are bookkeeping entries equivalent in value to one share of Predecessor Holdco common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The deferred stock units issued under the DSU Plan in respect to fiscal year 2013 (the &#147;2013 DSUs&#148;) were exchanged for the right to receive a cash
	payment in the aggregate amount of $1,323 in connection with the closing of the Merger Transaction. In connection with the Merger Transaction, the DSU Plan was terminated, and all deferred stock units outstanding thereunder were cancelled.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	84
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	15.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Derivatives and Hedging:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company uses derivative financial instruments to manage our exposures to (1)&nbsp;interest rate fluctuations on our floating rate senior
	debt; (2)&nbsp;price fluctuations in metal commodities used in our key products; and (3)&nbsp;fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates. The Company measures those instruments at fair value and recognizes changes in the fair value of
	derivatives in earnings in the period of change, unless the derivative qualifies as an effective hedge that offsets certain exposures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest Rate
	Swap Agreements
</B>
	- On June&nbsp;24, 2010, the Company entered into a forward Interest Rate Swap Agreement (the &#147;2010 Swap&#148;) with a two-year term for a notional amount of $115,000. The forward start date of the 2010 Swap was May&nbsp;31,
	2011 and it terminated on May&nbsp;31, 2013. The 2010 Swap fixed the interest rate at 2.47% plus the applicable interest rate margin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The 2010 Swap was
	initially designated as a cash flow hedge. Effective April&nbsp;18, 2011, the Company executed the second amendment to the Prior Credit Agreement which modified the interest rate on the Prior Senior Facilities (the &#147;Prior Senior
	Facilities&#148;). The critical terms for the 2010 Swap no longer matched the terms of the amended Prior Senior Facilities and the 2010 Swap was de-designated. As a result, $643 of previously unrecognized losses recorded as a component of other
	comprehensive income or loss was recognized as interest expense in year ended December&nbsp;31, 2011. The 2011 adjustments of $284 to the fair value of the 2010 Swap were recorded as a reduction in interest expense in the statement of comprehensive
	loss for the favorable change in fair value since December&nbsp;31, 2010.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2012, the fair value of the 2010 Swap was $(418) and was
	reported on the consolidated balance sheet in other current liabilities with a reduction in interest expense recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the favorable change of $787 in fair value since December&nbsp;31, 2011.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The 2010 Swap had no value at December&nbsp;31, 2014 or at December&nbsp;31, 2013. Adjustments of $418 to the fair value of the 2010 Swap were recorded as a
	reduction in interest expense in the statement of comprehensive loss for the favorable change in fair value from December&nbsp;31, 2012 until its termination on May&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;3, 2014, the Company entered into a forward Interest Rate Swap Agreement (the &#147;2014 Swap No.&nbsp;1&#148;) with a three-year term for a
	notional amount of $90,000. The forward start date of the 2014 Swap No.&nbsp;1 is October&nbsp;1, 2015 and its termination date is September&nbsp;30, 2018. The 2014 Swap No.&nbsp;1 fixes the interest rate at 2.2% plus the applicable interest rate
	margin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;3, 2014, the Company entered into a forward Interest Rate Swap Agreement (the &#147;2014 Swap No.&nbsp;2&#148;) with a
	three-year term for a notional amount of $40,000. The effective date of the 2014 Swap No.&nbsp;2 is October&nbsp;1, 2015 and its termination date is September&nbsp;30, 2018. The 2014 Swap No.&nbsp;2 fixes the interest rate at 2.2% plus the
	applicable interest rate margin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The total fair value of the interest rate swaps was $(935) as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and was reported on the
	consolidated balance sheet in other non-current liabilities with an increase in interest expense recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the unfavorable change of $935 in fair value since the inception.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	85
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	15.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Derivatives and Hedging: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s interest rate swap agreements did not qualify for hedge accounting treatment because they
	did not meet the provisions specified in ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging (&#147;ASC 815&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest Rate Cap Agreements -
</B>
	On May&nbsp;20,
	2013, the Company entered into an Interest Rate Cap Agreement (the &#147;2013 Rate Cap No.&nbsp;1&#148;) with a two-year term for a notional amount of $150,000 and the maximum LIBOR interest rate set at 1.25%. 2013 Rate Cap No.&nbsp;1 became
	effective on May&nbsp;28, 2013 and was terminated effective as of June&nbsp;19, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;20, 2013, the Company entered into an Interest Rate Cap
	Agreement (the &#147;2013 Rate Cap No.&nbsp;2&#148;) with a two-year term for a notional amount of $75,000 and the maximum LIBOR interest rate set at 1.25%. 2013 Rate Cap No.&nbsp;2 became effective on May&nbsp;28, 2013 and was terminated effective
	as of June&nbsp;19, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Adjustments of $(53) to the fair value of the rate caps were recorded as an increase in interest expense in the predecessor
	statement of comprehensive loss for the six months ended June&nbsp;29, 2014 for the unfavorable change since December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, the fair value of the interest rate caps of $53 was reported on the consolidated balance sheet in non-current other assets with an increase in interest expense recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the
	unfavorable change of $(81) in fair value since the inception.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s interest rate cap agreements did not qualify for hedge accounting
	treatment because they did not meet the provisions specified in ASC 815, Derivatives and Hedging, (&#147;ASC 815&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Metal Swap Agreements
</B>
	-
	On April&nbsp;20, 2012, the Company entered into a Commodity Metal Swap Agreement (the &#147;2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;1&#148;) with an approximate eight-month term for 35 MT of copper at a notional amount of $294.7. The maturity date was
	December&nbsp;31, 2012 and the 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;1 fixed the copper price at $8.42 per MT.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;30, 2012, the Company entered into a
	Commodity Metal Swap Agreement (the &#147;2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;2&#148;) with an approximate seven-month term for 10 MT of copper at a notional amount of $77.9. The maturity date was December&nbsp;31, 2012 and the 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;2 fixed
	the copper price at $7.79 per MT.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;30, 2012, the Company entered into a Commodity Metal Swap Agreement (the &#147;2012 Metal Swap
	No.&nbsp;3&#148;) with an approximate ten-month term for 35 MT of copper at a notional amount of $272.5. The maturity date was March&nbsp;31, 2013 and the 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;3 fixed the copper price at $7.785 per MT.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company uses metal commodity swap agreements to hedge anticipated purchases of key blanks which can fluctuate with changes in copper prices. The
	Company&#146;s current metal swap agreements did not qualify for hedge accounting treatment because they did not meet the provisions specified in ASC 815. Accordingly, the gain or loss on these derivatives was recognized in current earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	86
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage87"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">

</B>

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Derivatives and Hedging: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2012, the fair value of 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;1 was $17 and was reported on the
	consolidated balance sheet in other current assets with a decrease in cost of sales recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the favorable change in fair value since the inception date in the second quarter of 2012. At December&nbsp;31,
	2012, the fair value of 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;2 and 2012 Metal Swap No.&nbsp;3 was ($6) and was reported on the consolidated balance sheet in other current liabilities with an increase in cost of sales recorded in the statement of comprehensive
	loss for the unfavorable change in fair value since the inception dates in the second quarter of 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2013, each of the 2012
	metal swap agreements expired and had no value. A decrease in cost of sales was recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the favorable change in fair value since December&nbsp;31, 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Foreign Currency Forward Contracts
</B>
	- On December&nbsp;18, 2012, the Company entered into a Foreign Currency Forward Contract (the &#147;2012 FX
	Contract&#148;) with an approximate six-month term for a notional amount of C$105,000. The 2012 FX Contract maturity date was May&nbsp;21, 2013 and fixed the Canadian to U.S. dollar forward exchange rate at 0.9989. The purpose of the 2012 FX
	Contract was to manage the Company&#146;s exposure to fluctuations in the exchange rate of the Canadian dollar investment used in the Paulin Acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2012, the fair value of the 2012 FX Contract was ($1,475) and was reported on the consolidated balance sheet in other current liabilities
	with an increase in other expense recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the unfavorable change in fair value since its inception.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The 2012
	FX Contract was settled in connection with the Paulin Acquisition. Prior to its settlement on February&nbsp;19, 2013, an increase in other expense of $1,138 was recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the unfavorable change in fair value
	from December&nbsp;31, 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2013, the Company entered into multiple foreign currency forward contracts (the &#147;2013 FX Contracts&#148;) with
	maturity dates ranging from July 2013 to December 2014 and a total notional amount of C$44,591. The 2013 FX Contracts fixed the Canadian to U.S. dollar forward exchange rate at points ranging from 1.02940 to 1.08210. The purpose of the 2013 FX
	Contracts was to manage the Company&#146;s exposure to fluctuations in the exchange rate of the Canadian dollar.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2013, the fair
	value of the 2013 FX Contracts was ($42) and was reported on the consolidated balance sheet in other current liabilities with an increase in other expense of $42 recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, the Company entered into multiple foreign currency forward contracts (the &#147;2014 FX Contracts&#148;) with maturity dates ranging from March
	2014 to December 2015. The 2014 FX Contracts fixed the Canadian to U.S. dollar forward exchange rate at points ranging from 1.06800 to 1.1740. The purpose of the 2014 FX Contracts is to manage the Company&#146;s exposure to fluctuations in the
	exchange rate of the Canadian dollar.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	87
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage88"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<B>

</B>

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Derivatives and Hedging: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The total notional amount of contracts outstanding was C$31,032 and C$26,856 as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, respectively. The total fair value of the 2014 FX Contracts was $1,247 as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and was reported on the consolidated balance sheet in other current assets. An increase in other income of $1,289 was
	recorded in the statement of comprehensive loss for the favorable change in fair value from December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s FX Contracts did
	not qualify for hedge accounting treatment because they did not meet the provisions specified in ASC 815. Accordingly, the gain or loss on these derivatives was recognized in current earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not enter into derivative transactions for speculative purposes and, therefore, holds no derivative instruments for trading purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Additional information with respect to the fair value of derivative instruments is included in Note 16 &#150; Fair Value Measurements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	16.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Fair Value Measurements:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company uses the accounting guidance that applies to all assets and liabilities that are being measured and reported on a fair value
	basis. The guidance defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. The guidance also establishes a fair value
	hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. Assets and liabilities carried at fair value are classified and disclosed in one of the following three categories:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	Level&nbsp;1:
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Quoted market prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	Level&nbsp;2:
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Observable market-based inputs or unobservable inputs that are corroborated by market data.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	Level&nbsp;3:
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Unobservable inputs reflecting the reporting entity&#146;s own assumptions.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The accounting guidance
	establishes a hierarchy which requires an entity to maximize the use of quoted market prices and minimize the use of unobservable inputs. An asset or liability&#146;s level is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value
	measurement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	88
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>

	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>

	As of December 31,&nbsp;2013
<B>
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Trading securities are valued using quoted prices on an active exchange. Trading securities represent assets held in a Rabbi
	Trust to fund deferred compensation liabilities and are included as restricted investments on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the
	Successor period from June&nbsp;30, 2014 through December&nbsp;31, 2014, the unrealized gains on these securities of $43 were recorded as other income. The unrealized gains on these securities of $95, $364, and $329 were recorded as other income by
	the Predecessor for the six months period ended June&nbsp;29 and years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, and 2012, respectively. An offsetting entry for the same amount, increasing the deferred compensation liability and compensation expense within
	SG&amp;A, was also recorded for the corresponding periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company utilizes interest rate cap and interest rate swap contracts to manage our targeted
	mix of fixed and floating rate debt, and these contracts are valued using observable benchmark rates at commonly quoted intervals for the full term of the cap and swap contracts. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the interest rate swaps were included in
	other non-current liabilities on the accompanying consolidated balance sheet. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014 the interest rate caps had expired and had no value. As of December&nbsp;31, 2013 the interest rate caps were included in other current assets
	on the accompanying consolidated balance sheet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company utilizes foreign exchange forward contracts to manage our exposure to currency fluctuations
	in the Canadian dollar versus the U.S. dollar. The forward contracts were valued using observable benchmark rates at commonly quoted intervals during the term of the forward contract. The foreign exchange forward contracts were included in other
	current assets as of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and other current liabilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2013 on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	89
</P>

	The carrying amounts of the Company&#146;s cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, and accounts payable approximate
	fair value because of the short term maturity of these instruments and the carrying value of the variable rate senior term loans approximates fair value as the interest rate is variable and approximates current market rates.

	Additional information with respect to the derivative instruments is included in Note 15 &#150; Derivatives and Hedging. Additional information with respect
	to the Company&#146;s fixed rate senior notes and junior subordinated debentures is included in Note 9 &#150; Long-Term Debt.

<A NAME="eolPage91"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	17.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Commitments and Contingencies:
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company self-insures our product liability, automotive, workers&#146; compensation, and general liability losses up to $250 per
	occurrence. Catastrophic coverage has been purchased from third party insurers for occurrences in excess of $250 up to $40,000. The two risk areas involving the most significant accounting estimates are workers&#146; compensation and automotive
	liability. Actuarial valuations performed by the Company&#146;s outside risk insurance expert were used by the Company&#146;s management to form the basis for workers&#146; compensation and automotive liability loss reserves. The actuary
	contemplated the Company&#146;s specific loss history, actual claims reported, and industry trends among statistical and other factors to estimate the range of reserves required. Risk insurance reserves are comprised of specific reserves for
	individual claims and additional amounts expected for development of these claims, as well as for incurred but not yet reported claims. The Company believes that the liability of approximately $2,253 recorded for such risk insurance reserves is
	adequate as of December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company has provided certain vendors and insurers letters of credit aggregating
	$3,723 related to our product purchases and insurance coverage of product liability, workers&#146; compensation, and general liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company
	self-insures our group health claims up to an annual stop loss limit of $200 per participant. Aggregate coverage is maintained for annual group health insurance claims in excess of 125% of expected claims. Historical group insurance loss experience
	forms the basis for the recognition of group health insurance reserves. Provisions for losses expected under these programs are recorded based on an analysis of historical insurance claim data and certain actuarial assumptions. The Company believes
	that the liability of approximately $2,378 recorded for such group health insurance reserves is adequate as of December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;1,
	2013, Hillman Group filed a complaint against Minute Key Inc., a manufacturer of fully-automatic, self-service key duplication kiosks, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio (Western Division), seeking a declaratory
	judgment of non-infringement and invalidity of a U.S. patent issued to Minute Key Inc. on September&nbsp;10, 2013. Hillman Group&#146;s filing against Minute Key Inc. was in response to a letter dated September&nbsp;10, 2013 in which Minute Key Inc.
	alleged that Hillman Group&#146;s FastKey&#153; product infringes the newly-issued patent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;23, 2013, Minute Key Inc. filed an answer and
	counterclaim against Hillman Group alleging patent infringement. Minute Key Inc. also requested that the court dismiss Hillman Group&#146;s complaint, enter judgment against Hillman Group that we are willfully and deliberately infringing the patent,
	grant a permanent injunction, and award unspecified monetary damages to Minute Key Inc.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Minute Key Inc. later filed two motions on March&nbsp;17, 2014
	seeking to voluntarily withdraw its counterclaim alleging infringement by Hillman Group and also to dismiss Hillman Group&#146;s complaint for non-infringement and invalidity. Shortly after an April&nbsp;23, 2014 court-ordered mediation, Minute Key
	Inc. provided Hillman Group with a covenant promising not to sue for infringement of two of its patents against any existing Hillman Group product, including the FastKey&#153; and Key Express&#153; products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Hillman Group filed a motion on May&nbsp;9, 2014 seeking to add additional claims to the case against Minute Key Inc. under Federal and Ohio state unfair
	competition statutes. These claims relate to Minute Key Inc.&#146;s business conduct during competition with Hillman Group over a mutual client.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	91
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage92"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D858766D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	17.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Commitments and Contingencies: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In an August&nbsp;15, 2014 order, the court granted Minute Key Inc.&#146;s March&nbsp;17, 2014 motions to
	dismiss the claims relating to patent infringement, but also granted Hillman Group&#146;s May&nbsp;9, 2014 motion to add its unfair competition claims.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Hillman Group formally amended its complaint to add the unfair competition claims on September&nbsp;4, 2014, and Minute Key Inc. answered on
	September&nbsp;29, 2014 without filing any counterclaims. Minute Key Inc. filed a motion on October&nbsp;1, 2014 to move the case from Cincinnati to either the District of Colorado or the Western District of Arkansas. The court denied that motion on
	February&nbsp;3, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Because the lawsuit remains in a preliminary stage, it is not yet possible to assess the impact, if any, that the lawsuit will
	have on the Company. As a result of the Minute Key Inc. covenant not to sue, however, the Company&#146;s FastKey&#153; and Key Express&#153; products no longer face any threat of patent infringement liability from two of Minute Key Inc.&#146;s
	patents. The scope of the lawsuit has changed from a bilateral dispute over patent infringement to a lawsuit solely about Minute Key Inc.&#146;s business conduct. Hillman Group intends to continue to pursue this lawsuit vigorously and believes that
	it has meritorious claims for Minute Key Inc.&#146;s unfair competition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;14, 2014, PrimeSource Building Products, Inc., a supplier of
	products and materials in the building, construction, and do-it-yourself industries (&#147;PrimeSource&#148;), filed a complaint against Hillman Group in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas (Dallas Division) alleging
	trademark infringement, unfair competition, and unjust enrichment. On August&nbsp;8, 2014, Hillman Group filed a motion to dismiss the complaint and, on August&nbsp;29, 2014, PrimeSource filed an amended complaint. On September&nbsp;12, 2014,
	Hillman Group filed a motion to dismiss the amended complaint and, on October&nbsp;3, 2014, PrimeSource filed a response to the motion to dismiss the amended complaint. On October&nbsp;17, 2014, Hillman Group filed a reply in support of its motion
	to dismiss the amended complaint. The motion to dismiss the amended complaint remains pending before the court.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition to its earlier-filed
	complaint, PrimeSource filed a motion for preliminary injunction on July&nbsp;30, 2014. On August&nbsp;20, 2014, Hillman Group filed a response in opposition to the motion for preliminary injunction and, on September&nbsp;3, 2014, PrimeSource filed
	a reply in support of its motion for preliminary injunction. On October&nbsp;1, 2014, Hillman Group filed a surreply in opposition to the motion for preliminary injunction. The parties held a court hearing on the motion for preliminary injunction on
	March&nbsp;24 and 25, 2015 and the court announced that it intends to enter a ruling on the motion by March 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Because the lawsuit is in a
	preliminary stage, it is not yet possible to assess the impact, if any, that the lawsuit will have on the Company. However, Hillman Group believes that it has meritorious defenses to the claims and intends to defend the lawsuit vigorously. Also,
	Hillman Group&#146;s third party insurer has agreed to defend Hillman Group in the case subject to the right to withdraw its defense and/or to disclaim any obligation to indemnify Hillman Group, and reserving the right to seek a judicial
	determination that it is not obligated to defend or indemnify Hillman Group.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	92
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage93"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	THE HILLMAN COMPANIES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	(dollars in thousands)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Commitments and Contingencies: (continued)
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;15, 2014, Maria Santos, on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated, filed a
	complaint against Hillman Group and Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (&#147;Wal-Mart&#148;) in the United States District Court for the Central District of California (Western Division) alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the California
	Unruh Civil Rights Act, and the California Disabled Persons Act. On behalf of herself and all others similarly situated, Ms.&nbsp;Santos claims to seek, among other things, (1)&nbsp;a preliminary and permanent injunction to correct the alleged
	violations of these acts, (2)&nbsp;a declaration that Hillman Group and Wal-Mart are violating these acts, and (3)&nbsp;unspecified money damages, as well as recovery of court costs and attorneys&#146; fees. On January&nbsp;5, 2015, Hillman Group
	filed its answer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has paid a portion of the legal fees incurred by Wal-Mart and its affiliates in this lawsuit in connection with the
	agreement to license Hillman Group&#146;s products in Wal-Mart&#146;s stores, and expects to pay, in the future, the reasonable legal fees incurred by Wal-Mart in this case.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Because the lawsuit is in a preliminary stage, it is not yet possible to assess the impact or range of loss, if any, that the lawsuit will have on the
	Company. However, Hillman Group has retained counsel, believes that is has meritorious defenses to the claims, and intends to defend the lawsuit vigorously.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, legal proceedings are pending which are either in the ordinary course of business or incidental to the Company&#146;s business. Those legal
	proceedings incidental to the business of the Company are generally not covered by insurance or other indemnity. In the opinion of the Company&#146;s management, the ultimate resolution of the pending litigation matters will not have a material
	adverse effect on the consolidated financial position, operations, or cash flows of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	93
</P>
